column4: how do I have a program the rights to write a file to it's cwd if it lies in /usr/local/games/ ? It seems that applications can't write to there by default..
Anyone know how to give a program the permission to write a file to /usr/local/games/mygame ?
put it somewhere else?
/usr/local/* is usually owned by root, so you should have no need to write there...
I searched and found the recommendation that I should put installed programs in /usr/local and larger programs in /opt
This game writes a savesettings file but it can't since that's a root one :o was it a bad recommendation?
that's a general recommendation not a all-the-time recommendation
in some cases that's not what you do, in your case try it in /opt
if that doesn't work why not just run it out of your home direcotry
i dont want a lot of random programs' settings files cluttering up my home directory. Is /opt open to users or only root also? I need to abstract this to understand where I should put my programs
which "game" are you trying to run?
It's called Lantern which is an interface for chess program ICC. It's not in the repositories
run it from your home directory, that's the only way it can save data correctly.
or try one of the other chess programs out there.  (not sure what Lantern is though)

my .bashrc seems to have a setting to include /home/bin if it exists. I don't know what 'bin' is in general, i assume it's binaries for custom programs that I developed. Do you think I should put it in there or should I put a separate /home/games directory or something?
uh... what?
/home/YOURUSERNAMEHERE/bin might be one place to put stuff
I mean, is */bin in general a location I should put programs? or is that only for developers
its your system, run it from wherever you see fit.  I run half of my stuff on my servers as non-root, so...
thanks for the help
i usually run stuff out of individual directories for each program out of my home dir.
